pages.text: Pseudarthron whittingtoni comes from the upper Silurian, with fossils found in Slot Burn Formation, Scotland (UK). It the smallest cheloniellid, growing up to 1.6 cm in length.  Despite its small size, Pseudarthron is fairly important, from being the only known Silurian cheloniellid, to its discovery making palaeontologists come to the realisation that the previously described Triopus from the Ordovician,

which until this point had been referred to a myriad of different things, from trilobites to chitons, bore some similarities to it, and that Pseudarthron itself bore some similarities to Cheloniellon. This would eventually lead to Pseudarthron being assigned to family Cheloniellidae, alongside Triopus.

The generic name derives from the Greek words 'Pseudes', to mean 'false'; and 'Arthron', to mean 'joint'. The specific name derives from the surname of Professor H. B. Whittington, a British palaeontologist most well known for their extensive studies on the Burgess Shale.
